questions.question:
Question 1: A 40-year-old woman presents to the OPD with rapid weight gain and easy bruisability over 
the past 1 month. She was started on oral prednisolone for dermatomyositis 2 months ago. 
On examination, moon facies and abdominal striae are noted. Her BP is 160/110 mm Hg. 
Which of the following pathological changes is seen in this condition?

options.a: Corticotroph cells with homogenous and pale cytoplasm
options.b: Accumulation of keratin filaments in adrenal cells
options.c: Eosinophilic inclusion bodies in adrenal cells
options.d: Basophilic nuclear inclusion bodies in corticotroph cells

questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of iatrogenic Cushing's syndrome. In this condition, the 
normal basophilic cytoplasm of the corticotrophs of anterior pituitary becomes homogeneous and 
pale. This is termed the Crooke hyaline change and is due to the accumulation of intermediate 
keratin filaments in the cytoplasm. This change occurs due to high levels of circulating glucocorticoids in Cushing's syndrome. 1170 
Sold by @itachibot Based on the cause of Cushing's syndrome, the following pathological changes are seen in the 
adrenals: • Iatrogenic - atrophy of zona fasciculata and zona reticularis (as zona glomerulosa functions 
independently of ACTH) • ACTH-dependent - diffuse hyperplasia (due to high ACTH levels) • ACTH-independent - nodular hyperplasia, adenoma, or carcinoma Note: Eosinophilic inclusion bodies in adrenal cells are called spironolactone bodies. They are 
seen in Conn's syndrome.

questions.question:
Question 3: A 27-year-old woman is brought to the casualty with severe abdominal pain, diarrhea, and 
dizziness for the past 3 days. On examination, the following findings are noted. Blood 
pressure is 80/50 mm Hg and blood glucose is 48 mg/dl. Which of the following would you 
expect in this patient? 1164 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: High ACTH and low renin levels
options.b: High ACTH and high renin levels
options.c: Low ACTH and normal renin levels
options.d: Low ACTH and low renin levels

questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario and the image showing hyperpigmentation of palmar creases and oral 
mucosa are suggestive of primary adrenal insufficiency. It presents with low aldosterone, high 
renin, and high ACTH levels. In primary adrenal insufficiency, lack of aldosterone production results in compensatory rise in 
ACTH and renin levels. The high ACTH results in hyperpigmentation. The most common causes 
are autoimmune in developed countries and tuberculosis in developing countries. In secondary adrenal insufficiency, there is pituitary dysfunction leading to low ACTH levels. 
Renin and aldosterone levels are normal, as they function independently of ACTH.

questions.question:
Question 4: A 6-year-old boy was referred with fever, altered sensorium, and non-blanching rash for the 
past 2 days. He developed rapidly progressive shock and DIC. Despite resuscitation measures, 
he died. The following appearance of his adrenals was noted on autopsy. All of the following 
can cause this condition except: 1165 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario and image showing bilateral adrenal hemorrhage are suggestive 
of Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome. Neisseria gonorrhoeae is not a cause of this condition. It is caused by highly virulent organisms such as: • Neisseria meningitidis or meningococci (classically) • Streptococcus pneumoniae or pneumococci • Pseudomonas aeruginosa • Haemophilus influenzae • Staphylococcus species This condition is more common in children. Overwhelming bacterial infection leads to bilateral 
adrenal hemorrhage, thereby causing acute adrenal insufficiency. This is likely a result of direct 
bacterial seeding of small vessels and endothelial dysfunction caused by microbial products and 
inflammatory mediators. 1172 
Sold by @itachibot It usually presents with rapidly progressive hypotension and shock and disseminated 
intravascular coagulation (DIC) with widespread purpura. Without prompt recognition and 
treatment, death occurs within hours to a few days.

questions.question: Question 5: What is the most common cause of primary hyperaldosteronism?
questions.explanation:
Bilateral nodular hyperplasia of the adrenal glands is the most common cause of primary 
hyperaldosteronism. Adrenal adenoma is the second most common cause. It is usually solitary, but multiple adenomas 
may occur occasionally. Other rare causes include: • Ectopic aldosterone-producing tumors • Familial idiopathic hyperaldosteronism - due to germline mutations of KCNJ5 (encodes a 
potassium channel)

questions.question: Question 6: What is the underlying pathology in patients with Conn's syndrome?
questions.explanation:
The underlying pathology in patients with Conn's syndrome is adrenal adenoma. Hyperaldosteronism may be primary or secondary. Primary hyperaldosteronism is due to autonomous overproduction of aldosterone with resultant 
suppression of RAAS. It can occur due to adrenal hyperplasia, adenoma, or carcinoma. It presents 
with the following features: • Hypertension (most common) • Hypokalemia • Metabolic alkalosis • Polyuria (due to ANP) • Polydipsia (due to polyuria) • Muscle weakness It is confirmed by elevated ratios of plasma aldosterone concentration to plasma renin activity 
(PAC / PRA). When primary hyperaldosteronism is due to an aldosterone-secreting adenoma, it is called Conn 
syndrome. Patients are usually treated with spironolactone followed by surgical removal of 
adenoma. In patients treated with spironolactone, the adenomas contain eosinophilic cytoplasmic 
inclusions called spironolactone bodies. 1173 
Sold by @itachibot In secondary hyperaldosteronism, aldosterone release occurs in response to the activation of the 
renin-angiotensin system (RAAS).

questions.question:
Question 7: Patients with which of the following conditions are not at risk of developing adrenocortical 
carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
MEN2B syndrome is associated with pheochromocytoma and medullary carcinoma of thyroid, 
not adrenocortical carcinoma. Adrenocortical carcinoma is associated with the following hereditary cancer syndromes: • Li–Fraumeni syndrome - due to germline TP53 mutations • Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome - a disorder of epigenetic imprinting • MEN1 syndrome - due to mutations of MEN1 gene 1174 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: A 7-year-old boy is brought for the evaluation of recurrent seizures over the last 3 months. 
Past history is significant for chronic oral candidiasis for 2 years. On examination, nail 1166 
Sold by @itachibot dystrophy is noted. Further investigation reveals serum calcium of 6.9 mg/dl and prolonged 
QT interval. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of autoimmune polyendocrinopathy (APS) type 1. It is also 
called APECED (autoimmune polyendocrinopathy, candidiasis, and ectodermal dystrophy). It is caused by mutations in the autoimmune regulator (AIRE) gene. This gene usually increases 
tolerance of central T-cells to peripheral tissue antigens. When this function is lost, the T-cells 
become more prone to mount immune reactions against tissue antigens, promoting 
autoimmunity. These patients develop autoantibodies against IL-17 and IL-22, which are crucial 
for defense against fungal infections. It presents in childhood with the following features: • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis • Ectodermal dystrophy (abnormalities of the skin, dental enamel, and nails) • Organ-specific autoimmune disorders such as - • Autoimmune adrenalitis • Autoimmune hypoparathyroidism • Idiopathic hypogonadism • Pernicious anemia Autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome (APS) type 2 usually presents in early adulthood as a 
combination of the following: • Adrenal insufficiency • Autoimmune thyroiditis or type 1 diabetes

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following is most commonly involved in Wermer syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Primary hyperparathyroidism is the most common manifestation of Wermer’s syndrome or 
MEN-1 syndrome. MEN1 syndrome is due to germline mutations in the MEN1 tumor-suppressor gene, which 
encodes a protein called menin. The most commonly secreted products are pancreatic 
polypeptides.

questions.question:
Question 11: Which of the following is an indicator of malignant transformation in a patient with 
pheochromocytoma?
questions.explanation:
The definitive diagnosis of malignancy in pheochromocytomas is based exclusively on the 
presence of metastases to regional lymph nodes as well as distant sites like liver, lung, and bone. Capsular and vascular invasion may be encountered even in benign lesions. Malignant 
pheochromocytomas are histologically and biochemically the same as benign ones. Hence, typical 
histological criteria like cellular atypia, mitotic spindles, and vascular invasion are insufficient to 
confirm malignancy in pheochromocytomas.

questions.question:
Question 12: A pathologist is studying the following slide from the biopsy of a patient with an abdominal 
mass. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given histopathology slide shows nests of cells arranged in an organoid pattern, with 
fibrovascular septae, and finely granular cytoplasm. This is called the zellballen pattern. It is 
typically seen in paragangliomas and pheochromocytomas. Paragangliomas are benign neuroendocrine tumors arising from paraganglia in the neck or 
abdomen. They are composed of chief and sustentacular cells arranged in an organoid pattern. 1176 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 13: A 38-year-old woman was being evaluated for persistent hypertension. Workup revealed a 
tumor located near the bifurcation of the aorta. Surgical excision was done and HPE 
examination revealed a zellballen pattern of cells. Where did this tumor likely originate from?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of a paraganglioma (ectopic pheochromocytoma) located in the 
abdomen. They commonly arise from the organ of Zuckerkandl, located at the bifurcation of the 
aorta. It is part of the vertebral paraganglia (clusters of chromaffin cells along the autonomic 
nerve chains). Other sites of origin of paragangliomas include: • Urinary bladder - rarely • Carotid and aortic bodies • Ganglion nodosum of the vagus nerve • Jugulotympanic ganglia 1177 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 14: 1168 
Sold by @itachibot What mutation is likely to be seen in patients with familial paraganglioma syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Familial paraganglioma is most likely associated with mutations in the SDH (succinate 
dehydrogenase) gene. The SDH complex is involved in mitochondrial electron transport and oxygen sensing. It is 
believed that SDH mutations also lead to the upregulation of HIF-1, which is a key oncogenic 
driver in this type of tumor.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 21-year-old young man presents with a neck mass. Past history is significant for surgical 
removal of a pheochromocytoma 6 months ago. On examination, a marfanoid habitus is 
noted along with the following finding. Which of the following should the patient be screened 
for?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario and image showing mucosal neuromas are suggestive of MEN2B syndrome. 
This condition is associated with medullary carcinoma of the thyroid. The MEN syndromes are a group of inherited diseases of multiple endocrine 
organs. Tumors occur at a younger age than sporadic tumors, either synchronously (at the same 
time) or metachronously (at different times). MEN2 syndrome occurs due to abnormal activation of the RET gene. Medullary carcinoma is seen 
in both MEN 2A and 2B syndromes. However, it tends to be more aggressive and metastasizes 
more frequently in MEN2B syndrome. Note: RET gene is deactivated in Hirschsprung disease.

questions.question: Question 16: What gene is mutated in polycythemia paraganglioma syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Polycythemia paraganglioma syndrome occurs due to germline mutations in the EPAS1 gene. This 
syndrome presents with neuroendocrine tumors and early-onset polycythemia. RET gene mutation is seen in MEN2A and MEN2B syndromes. SDHD and SDHB mutations are seen in hereditary paraganglioma 1 and hereditary 
paraganglioma 4 syndromes respectively. 1178 
Sold by @itachibot The Breast
